oai_dc:dc.dc:title: WAVE TRANSFORMATION NEAR A QUASI-1D COAST
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gal, J.H. Andorka
Holthuijsen, L.H.
de Jong, J.C.M.
Kieftenburg, A.T.M.M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: wave transformation
quasi-1D coast
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two sets of observations of wave transformation near two quasi one-dimensional coasts, from deep water (22 m) to shallow water (0.5 m) have been simulated with the third-generation spectral wave model SWAN. The first set of observations contains wind waves that are generated by a local storm off the North Sea coast of the Netherlands. The second set contains a mix of swell and local wind waves at the Pacific coast of Japan. Repeated computations without triad wave-wave interactions show that the inclusion of this process in the model is essential. A f ^dependency of the depth-induced dissipation (rather than the conventional frequency independence in SWAN), causes too much energy dissipation in the high frequencies, shifting the mean frequency to too low values.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 26 (1998): Proceedings of 26th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Copenhagen, Denmark, 1998.
